thread.title: Tasmania's Tarkine: Ancient history should qualify area as national park, groups say - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
thread.title_full: Tasmania's Tarkine: Ancient history should qualify area as national park, groups say - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)

author: Carla Howarth
title: Tasmania's Tarkine: Ancient history should qualify area as national park, groups say - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)
text:
Map: Arthur River 7330 
Thirty-five new sites of Aboriginal heritage significance have been discovered on Tasmania's Tarkine coastline, renewing calls for the area to be declared a national park. 
Volunteers from the Tasmanian Aboriginal Centre (TAC) and the Wilderness Society found middens, artefact scatters and stone tools in the wilderness region, in Tasmania's north-west. 
Wilderness Society spokesperson Vica Bayley said the group not only surveyed for sites of Aboriginal significance, but also removed hundreds of kilograms of rubbish over four days. 
"It absolutely builds on the campaign to properly protect and respect this landscape," he said. Photo: Volunteers collected "tonnes" of rubbish while surveying in the Tarkine, organisers said. (Supplied: The Wilderness Society) 
"The knowledge that will come from this expedition will actually feed into the case against the Hodgman Government expanding destructive four-wheel-drive tracks across this coastline. 
"Despite losing two court cases to say that the impact on Aboriginal heritage of expanding these tracks would be unacceptable, they appear determined to refer the matter to the Federal Environment Minister Josh Frydenberg for assessment under federal environment law." 
In the 2014 election, the then-Labor government promised it would reopen the tracks in the Arthur-Pieman Conservation Area which had been closed due to concerns about Aboriginal site damage. The TAC sought an injunction and court action followed. Photo: A trailer-load of rubbish is taken away from the Tarkine area. (Supplied: The Wilderness Society) 
Mr Bayley said despite the coastline being remote, the impact of humans was "writ large". 
"There's the powerful, positive legacy left by countless generations of Aboriginal occupation of this landscape, whilst on the flipside there are tonnes and tonnes of rubbish and evidence of ongoing illegal four-wheel-drive use in the area," he said. 
Aboriginal heritage worker Sharnie Everett said cultural landscapes such as the Tarkine should be protected. 
"It is collaborations such as this that are helping the Aboriginal community to expand the understanding of these highly important cultural landscapes," she said. 
"To highlight the depth of history they contain and the importance of Aboriginal control of the protection and management of them into the future. 
"The history of this island, and this heritage, should be protected for the benefit of all Tasmanians." 
The expedition was the first in an ongoing program that will cover 40 kilometres of coastline between the Pieman River and Sandy Cape. Photo: The legal fight over access to the Tarkine is still before the courts. (Supplied: The Wilderness Society) Court process ongoing 
In March last year, the Federal Court sided with the TAC, which had argued allowing vehicles into the area would damage places of Indigenous significance, including middens. 
Last year, the full bench of the Federal Court said the State Government could appeal the decision. It asked the parties to try to agree on a way forward, giving them options to send the case back to court or refer the plan to reopen the tracks to the Federal Government. 
Under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act, any action that will have a significant impact on heritage values must be referred to Mr Frydenberg for assessment. 
A spokesman for Mr Frydenberg said no referral had been submitted.
